1: Did you know, that regular physical activity improves your physical abilities.
2: Did you know, that regular physical activity reduces your risk of fall.
3: Did you know, that insufficient physical activity can be a reason for depressive mood and loneliness.
4: Did you know, that regular physical activity helps you to manage stress.
5: Did you know, that regular physical activity improves your sleeping patterns.
6: Did you know, that insufficient physical activity increases your risk for joint and back pain.
7: Did you know, that regular physical activity improves your mobility and balance.
8: Did you know, that regular physical activity improves your heart and respiratory performance.
9: Did you know, that insufficient physical activity is one of the indirect leading factors for death worldwide.
10: Did you know, that regular physical activity improves your quality of life.
11: One of the five golden rules for physical activity is to try be as physically active as your abilities and conditions allow.
12: One of the five golden rules for physical activity is to try to perform activities in short bouts of 10 minutes duration.
13: One of the five golden rules for physical activity is to reduce your sitting time with regular standing up breaks every 30 minutes.
14: One of the five golden rules for physical activity is to include physical activity in your daily life activities based on the recommended values.
15: One of the five golden rules for physical activity is to know that every minute of activity counts.
16: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale is a measure of subjective perceived exertion during physical activity with different ranges.
17: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale varies from very light activity (1), light activity (2-3), moderate activity (4-5) to vigorous activity (5-6).
18: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale defines very light activity (1) as any activity other than complete rest.
19: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale defines light activity (2-3) as it feels like you can maintain it for hours while easily breathing.
20: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale defines moderate activity (4-5) as you can hold short conversations while exercising.
21: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale defines vigorous activity (6-7) as feels like you on the verge of uncomfortable with short of breath.
22: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale Includes as very light activities for example: Folding laundry or washing dishes.
23: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale includes as light activities for example: Walking slowly or vacuuming.
24: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale includes as moderate activities for example: Walking briskly or swimming.
25: The Rate of Perceived Exertion Scale includes as vigorous activities for example: Jogging or carrying heavy loads.
26: The World Health Organisation recommends to perform three activity-forms per week: Aerobic, muscle strength and balance training.
27: The World Health Organisation recommends to conduct aerobic exercises, for example swimming, 150-300 minutes per week.
28: The World Health Organisation recommends to conduct muscle strength exercises, for example lifting weights, on 2 days per week.
29: The World Health Organisation recommends to conduct balance exercises, for example heel raises, on 3 days per week.
30: The World Health Organisation recommends to combine aerobic, muscle strength and balance exercises in your physical activity weekly routine.
31: Here is a practical tip to be active: Walking in the fresh air can be a mood buster, it improves your mind and body.
32: Here is a practical tip to be active: Household activities, like vacuum cleaning or wiping keep you fit and independent.
33: Here is a practical tip to be active: Conducting yard work, like pulling out weed, will make your arm muscles stronger. Practicing this regularly, carrying groceries can be easier.
34: Here is a practical tip to be active: Performing heel raises while holding on to a chair back can help you to improve your balance. Practicing this regularly, it can prevent falls.
35: Here is a practical tip to be active: Going up and down the stairs, by holding on the rail, will make your leg muscles stronger. Practicing regularly, sitting down and standing up will be easier for you.
